Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Electrohydrodynamic 3D Printing for Super-Resolution Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research on high-resolution additive manufacturing based on electrohydrodynamic 3D printing of melted thermoplastic materials. This research will develop a melt electrohydrodynamic printing process for thermoplastic materials to achieve high precision additive manufacturing of complex objects with single micron-scale resolution, which will overcome the resolution barrier of most existing additive manufacturing approaches and significantly improve the accuracy and surface finish of the produced parts. Theoretical and empirical process models will be investigated for the analysis of the melt electrohydrodynamic printing process with respect to material properties and process parameters. This research will integrate process development, process modeling, and a novel manufacturing system into a new framework that enables high-resolution 3D printing of complex industrial and biomedical products.

The research has potential to advance the emerging additive manufacturing industry by providing a low-cost high-resolution 3D printing process for the manufacturing of high precision parts with superior surface finish. Additive manufacturing have became a fast growing industry that enables rapid prototyping or production of components for automotive, aerospace, and medical applications. Considering the demanding requirements on the resolution and accuracy of the industrial products and advanced biomedical scaffolds, this research will provide a transformative approach that solves the long-existing resolution limitation of current additive manufacturing approaches. Moreover, the multidisciplinary education program in this project will link the research outcomes and students' activities to the needs of the industry for additive manufacturing, super-resolution printing, and instrumentation. The project will also contribute to undergraduate education, provide research experience for undergraduate and minority students, and disseminate discoveries to K-12 students through its outreach program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research is to investigate a high-resolution electrohydrodynamic (EHD) 3D printing process with thermoplastic materials to achieve high precision additive manufacturing of complex objects. The proposed process overcomes the resolution barrier of most existing additive manufacturing approaches. This research incorporates process innovation, process modeling, and a novel manufacturing system into a new framework that enables super-resolution 3D printing of complex industrial and biomedical products.

In this project, we developed the EHD printing process for a broad set of functional materials to fabricate micro-scale 2D patterns and 3D structures with unsurpassed resolution compared to conventional printing methods. EHD printing is a high-resolution printing method, in which the printing materials are subjected to a high electrostatic field to form a Taylor-cone structure, and a fine jet or droplet ejected from the cone. The diameter of the jet/droplet is significantly smaller than the nozzle size, which can overcome the limitation of the nozzle size for better resolution to produce micro and nano-scale feature. We successfully developed a drop-on-demand printing process and a direct filament plotting process for the high-resolution fabrication of functional materials with different material properties. We applied EHD drop-on-demand printing for phase-change inks (i.e. wax) in the fabrication of high aspect-of-ratio 3D structures with sub-10 μm feature resolution, and EHD direct plotting for a molten thermoplastic polymer, polycaprolactone (PCL), in the fabrication of 2D patterns and 3D periodic porous scaffold structures with about 5 µm feature resolution. It is very difficult, if not at all impossible, to achieved such resolution with traditional fabrication approaches, such as ink-jet printing and fused-deposition modeling (FDM). In this work, besides the polymer-based inks, we also applied EHD printing to many other functional materials, including molten metal inks, silver nanoink, and ZnO nanoparticle-based ink, for 3D printing and the fabrication of flexible and stretchable electronic devices. The feature dimension and ejection speed can be precisely controlled by regulating the conditions of the printing process.

In this project, we investigated a novel EHD printing system by developing a self-functioning print head with all electrodes integrated with the nozzle for robust 3D printing. In the traditional setup of EHD printing, the substrate is used as a planar electrode to provide voltage difference with respect to the nozzle, which limited its capability for 3D manufacturing. We designed and integrated a ring electrode with the printing nozzle to achieve a self-working printer head, which can start and maintain the printing process without the involvement of the substrate. The printing system with the integrated ring extractor provided high-resolution printing of high aspect of ratio 3D structures.

This project also investigated a modeling framework to model the EHD drop-on-demand printing process, including the droplet formation at the nozzle tip and the droplet settlement on the substrate. The droplet formation and the droplet spreading and settlement was modeled with the help of Finite Element Analysis (FEA). The results from the FEA models matched well with the experimental results, which provided a valuable method to predict the process performance and to optimize the process.

The research from this project advances the additive manufacturing technology by providing a high-resolution 3D printing process and developing a printing system for the rapid manufacturing of high precision parts using different functional materials. Considering the demanding requirements on the resolution and accuracy of industrial products, advanced biomedical scaffolds, and printed electronics, this research provides a transformative framework for technology innovation that helps to solve the long-existing resolution limitation of the current printing and additive manufacturing approaches. The research results have been broadly disseminated through technical publications, workshops, courses, and K-12 outreach activities. A few graduate students have been mentored in this project to train future workforce in high-resolution printing. Lab modules were developed to provide graduate students with hands-on experience in micro-scale additive manufacturing in a graduate level course ISE718: micro/nano fabrication. This project also provided demonstrations and lab tours for high school students in NCSU Summer Camp, and for the undergraduate students in Summer school. A few undergraduate students were hosted and supervised to work on the related topics as their summer REU projects.

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2018
Modified by: Jingyan Dong
